awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Collaborative Research: Transforming Electrocatalysis using Rational Design of Two Dimensional Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will employ an integrated theoretical and experimental approach to rapidly discover highly efficient catalysts, based on two-dimensional (2D) materials in contact with an ionic liquid, for a variety of electrochemical reactions of importance for sustainable energy generation, chemicals manufacturing, environmental remediation, and energy storage.  Electrocatalysis - as employed in energy storage and conversion devices such as advanced batteries, fuel cells, photovoltaics, and chemical electrolyzers - is becoming an increasingly important alternative to conventional thermal catalysis, but needs further improvements in efficiency, cost reduction, and chemical selectivity for wide-scale commercial implementation.  The project will address those needs by combining first-principles density functional theory calculations, including solvent interaction effects and theory-guided machine learning, to identify new ionic-liquid electrolytes and low-cost 2D materials capable of displacing existing thermal processes with electrocatalytic processes utilizing renewable and/or sustainable resources.  Educational and outreach components of the project will focus on preparing both graduate and undergraduate students for the workforce needed to realize advanced energy technologies.  Emphasis at both universities will be placed on the recruitment of minority and underrepresented student populations through existing programs including the Minority Engineering Recruitment and Retention Program (MERRP) at the University of Illinois-Chicago, and the Office of Undergraduate Research at Washington University.  The theoretical and experimental dataset on 2D materials generated in the study, along with relevant computational codes, will be disseminated to the broader research community through on-line repositories.

Two-dimensional transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs) in contact with ionic liquid (IL) electrolytes will be used as the starting materials offering a new paradigm for electrocatalysis based on materials with low work function, significant overlap of the d-band partial density of states with the Fermi energy, and an electrolyte 'solvent' that protects rather than poisons the catalytic sites.  Novel material combinations and structures will be predicted using computational tools and then synthesized using chemical vapor deposition, chemical vapor transport and colloidal chemistry. Atomic and electronic structure will be characterized using in-situ aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM).  The information obtained from high-resolution STEM, including high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) and annular bright-field (ABF) imaging, as well as electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (XEDS), will be used to confirm successful synthesis of the desired structures and to create starting configurations for the first-principles modeling efforts.  Both ex-situ and in-situ electrochemical experiments will be conducted to measure the activity and selectivity of the synthesized materials.  In particular, the study will utilize a novel graphene liquid cell, developed by one of the investigators, that enables atomic-resolution imaging and spectroscopy in a liquid environment. Mechanistic studies of the electrocatalytic reactions and transport measurements will be made utilizing in-situ differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) together with a traditional silicon nitride based electrochemical stage for STEM characterization under operando conditions.  Taken together, the advanced synthesis, characterization, and evaluation techniques, coupled with efficient computational search methods, will accelerate the discovery of 2D material-based-catalysts with superior activity and selectivity for various electrochemical reactions including the oxygen reduction reaction (important in fuel cell technology), and the hydrogen evolution reaction (important in water electrolysis).
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes 

The objective of this proposal was to use an integrated theoretical and experimental approach to rapidly discover highly efficient catalysts, based on two-dimensional (2D) materials for a variety of electrochemical reactions. In the first year of this DMREF program, our team investigated highly efficient catalysts, based transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs) for oxygen reduction and evolution reactions (ORR/OER). Later, selected catalysts were studied in Li-air batter system and outstanding results including exceptional cyclability up to 700 cycles were achieved. Based on this research the team developed the first generation of real Li-Air battery systems that operate with all air compounds and impurities. The results of Li-Air battery research were published in Nature. The team also performed first-principles investigation of the stability and electronic property of TMDC materials with the goal of developing theoretical analyses of stability as a function of composition and synthesis temperature of materials. 

In the second of this project, the team established a joint-theoretical and experimental framework to develop a rational-design approach for the synthesis of quasi-binary TMDC alloys by efficiently navigating their vast compositional space. Equilibrium temperature-composition phase diagrams were established using first-principles calculations to identify the region of stability for 25 quasi-binary TMDC alloys. These theoretical predictions were confirmed by synthesizing a subset of 12 predicted alloys. Multi-scale characterization was performed to provide feedback to both the materials modeling and the synthesis efforts of this project. The synthesized materials were tested in different electrochemical systems and their electronic properties were studied comprehensively.

In this third year, the team continued the collaboration to finish the initial work in developing equilibrium phase diagrams to guide the synthesis of binary TMDC alloys and start working on high entropy alloy (HEA) structures. The first TMDC HEA was synthesized and characterized by the team. Also, it was tested for CO2 reduction reaction which resulted in a record activity for this reaction. Computations were used to the described the reaction pathways and mechanism for this multinary structures. New approaches were developed to characterize the effects of structural modification to 2D material, including transition metal dichalcogenides and MXenes. Given the numerous degrees-of-freedom associated with various 2D materials (composition, chemical order, defects, edge structure and termination), atomic-scale information obtained from STEM characterization was used as a guide to build realistic models that include the observed features to understand their effect on the catalytic activity. Additionally, in this year, the team explored two-dimensional (2D) Cu based conductive metal organic frameworks (c-MOF) in Li-air batteries. The cycling and energy efficiency of the battery were studied under different current density rates accompanied with calculations and various characterization techniques.

In the fourth year of this DMREF program, the team focused on the in-situ electrochemical experiment using STEM, design and synthesis of multinary alloys of 1d/2D TMDCs, developing a robust framework to predict the thermodynamic stability of high-entropy alloys as a function of composition and temperature, and synthesis, characterization and testing of multifunctional 1D TMDC alloy structures based on our understanding of 2D alloys. The synthesized structures were tested for CO2 conversion reaction, electric transport, and thermal breakdown. 

 

 


Last Modified: 02/17/2023
Modified by: Amin Salehi-Khojin

Outcomes 

The objective of this proposal was to use an integrated theoretical and experimental approach to rapidly discover highly efficient catalysts, based on two-dimensional (2D) materials for a variety of electrochemical reactions. In the first year of this DMREF program, our team investigated highly efficient catalysts, based transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs) for oxygen reduction and evolution reactions (ORR/OER). The results of Li-Air battery research were published in Nature. In this third year, the team continued the collaboration to finish the initial work in developing equilibrium phase diagrams to guide the synthesis of binary TMDC alloys and start working on high entropy alloy (HEA) structures. The first TMDC HEA was synthesized and characterized by the team. Also, it was tested for CO2 reduction reaction which resulted in a record activity for this reaction. Computations were used to the described the reaction pathways and mechanism for this multinary structures. New approaches were developed to characterize the effects of structural modification to 2D material, including transition metal dichalcogenides and MXenes. In the fourth year of this DMREF program, the team focused on the in-situ electrochemical experiment using STEM, design and synthesis of multinary alloys of 1d/2D TMDCs, developing a robust framework to predict the thermodynamic stability of high-entropy alloys as a function of composition and temperature, and synthesis, characterization and testing of multifunctional 1D TMDC alloy structures based on our understanding of 2D alloys. The synthesized structures were tested for CO2 conversion reaction, electric transport, and thermal breakdown.
